abstract.p: The paper expounds a non-cooperative game that can be interpreted as a model of the system of kula that was described by Bronislaw Malinowski in his Argonauts of the Western Pacific. The game of kula is an infinite-horizon game with an arbitrary, but fixed, number n of players. It generates pure norms of direct reciprocity, pure norms of indirect reciprocity, and mixed norms whereby a player who deviates is punished both by the individual who has been harmed and by a third party.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In a classic of anthropology, Malinowski (1984 [1922]) described in detail a peculiar pattern of interaction among islanders of the Western Pacific. That pattern, which he called the kula, linked the residents of several islands and involved a succession of gifts and counter-gifts of necklaces and arm-shells. Necklaces travelled from one island to another in a clockwise manner; and arm-shells, in a counter-clockwise fashion.

Partnership in the kula was a lifelong affair. The institution itself was permanent. When kula participants died, they were replaced by the heirs of their kula valuables. In order to exchange gifts, natives made periodic overseas expeditions, whose exact timing depended upon factors such as the winds or the weather. Those expeditions required great navigation skills on their part. They also demanded a lot of time and effort in their preparation.

During an expedition, the host partner would make a gift to the guest partner. That gift would be reciprocated later, when the host had become the guest; and the guest, the host. A fundamental rule was that a participant always received from a given partner gifts of the same type (say, necklaces), and always gave that partner gifts of the other type (say, arm-shells).

Besides taking part in the kula, residents of different islands also bartered with one another. Most importantly for our purposes, Malinowski noted they had different words in their languages for the two activities and they made a clear distinction between them. In particular, they blamed those who conducted kula as if it were barter. A satisfactory explanation of the kula must, therefore, go beyond the ‘double coincidence of wants’ that one can use to explain barter. It must explain the constitution of a social order.

The paper expounds a mathematical model of the kula. Its structure is that of a non-cooperative and infinite-horizon game in the sense of game theorists, such as Fudenberg and Tirole (1991). It makes three main points. The first is that game theory can model the order of real societies, as opposed to imaginary ones. Indeed, Sugden (2004), Binmore (1994; 1998; 2005), Skirms (1996), and many others, have argued in principle that game theory can provide an explanation of social order. However, they have generally produced models that are artificial and refer to imaginary societies. An important exception is Greif (2006), who constructed models of some medieval institutions. By attempting to model the order of a society that actually existed, the paper aims to make that literature, if not fully realistic, at least marginally more so.

The second point is that the kula can be explained easily, once we take a rational choice perspective and make the same assumptions about the rationality of its participants that economists make casually about businessmen and financiers in order to explain their behaviour. Indeed, the model uses little more than the fundamentals of game theory, and the kula follows naturally from its simple mathematical hypotheses.

The third, and final, point is that the general presumption in the literature that the kula is a system of indirect reciprocity should be qualified, as it is only one among many interpretations that are logically consistent. More precisely, the paper proves the kula can be generated by pure norms of direct reciprocity, where a player who deviates is punished only by a player who has been harmed; pure norms of indirect reciprocity, where the sanction is carried out by a third party only; and, mixed norms, where the player who deviates is punished both by a player who has been harmed and by a third party.

The explanation of the kula that the model provides has the following properties: actors who make rational choices; choices that entail the constitution of norms of reciprocity; norms of reciprocity that entail themselves the three obligations that are at the foundations of gift exchange, according to Mauss (1923–24): to give, to receive, and to give back; norms of reciprocity that also entail a flow of two valuables, which is such that an actor always receives from a given partner a valuable of the same type, and always gives to that partner a valuable of the other type; and, finally, a flow of valuables that is mutually advantageous for all actors and makes the kula a system of social exchange. All those properties follow from the fundamentals of the model by logical necessity. Furthermore, they are derived by the means of a deductive argument, with formal mathematical proof at each and every step.

Our model can be compared to other explanations of the kula that are found in the literature. At one extreme, it contrasts markedly with the sociological tradition that follows Mauss (1923–24) and assumes the kula to be ‘a total social fact’. Indeed, from that perspective, a rational choice analysis is not even possible and the kula requires a holistic explanation. That literature is reviewed in Carrier (1991).

Other explanations that have been proposed are friendlier to a rational choice approach and can be related to elements of our model. Indeed, authors such as Homans (1961) and Blau (1964) have interpreted the kula in terms of social exchange. Writing from a public choice perspective, Landa (1983), and Grofman and Landa (1983), have argued that the kula ring is an institution that economises on the costs of exchange.

Now, it is well known in economic theory that exchanges can fail to take place, even though they would be mutually advantageous, when there is a market imperfection. Indeed, economists who analyse the inefficiencies associated with monopolies, oligopolies, public goods, external effects, increasing returns, information problems, etc., discuss such exchanges that do not take place; see, for instance, Varian (1992). In social theory, Yamagishi and Cook (1993) have pointed out similarly that social exchange can only happen under proper incentives.

Moreover, Gouldner (1960) has argued conclusively that any explanation of reciprocal gifts in terms of social exchange implies a norm of reciprocity as a necessary assumption, whether it is explicit or implicit. The existence of such a norm, however, is itself in need of an explanation. Indeed, sociologists have been aware of the possibility of anomie ever since Durkheim (1986 [1893]).

Finally, Ziegler (2007; 2008) has constructed simulation models of the kula. When they are interpreted as heuristic devices, such simulations can provide valuable insights. As he acknowledges himself, however, it is more satisfactory to construct a deductive model and to solve it analytically, when that can be done. (Ziegler, 2008, page 112).

The paper is self-contained and proceeds as follows. In section I, I expound a one-off game that is an abstract version of the constitutive game of Boyd and Richerson (1989). My circular game has an arbitrary, but fixed, number n of players whose actions generate external effects. Those external effects have an algebraic structure that defines the pattern of interactions between the players. More precisely, the payoffs are parameterised by a permutation of the players. That assumption allows the model to capture those loops of interactions that are characteristic of the kula. The section also proves that both the one-off prisoner’s dilemma and the one-off circular game have a unique Nash equilibrium that is Pareto-inefficient.

In section II, I expound the formal definition of the game of kula as the infinite-horizon game that takes place when two different circular games are repeated alternatively and indefinitely often with the same rational players. In section III, I prove that both the indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma and the game of kula have multiple equilibriums. In both cases, actors do not cooperate along at least one equilibrium path; and cooperate along at least another one, when their discount factors are high enough. Naturally, actors unanimously prefer the latter to the former.

In section IV, I explain how the game that was constructed can be interpreted as a model of the kula. More generally, I show that the game of kula can model systems of bidirectional social exchange, such as that found by Bearman (1997) behind the exchange of women among residents of Groote Eylandt in the 1940s.

In section V, I complete my analysis and show three different types of social norms can be constituted in the game of kula: pure norms of direct reciprocity, pure norms of indirect reciprocity, and mixed norms that involve elements of direct and indirect reciprocity.

Finally, in section VI, I discuss the realism of the information structure that the game of kula assumes. I also demonstrate that the game of kula can model a kula that persists, despite eventual mistakes on the part of its participants.

sec.title: I. The one-off circular game

The preceding assumptions define a game. I call it the game of circular external effects (or, in short, the circular game). Two cases deserve to be considered in this analysis.

When n = 2, the game of circular external effects reduces to a prisoner’s dilemma. Strategy A is then referred to as cooperation; and strategy B, as defection. The analysis of the prisoner’s dilemma can be found in several textbooks. See, for instance, Binmore (1994; 1998) or Fudenberg and Tirole (1991). In what follows, we will take it for granted and discuss the case where n is arbitrary.

It is well known that the prisoner’s dilemma has a unique Nash equilibrium that is made of strictly dominant strategies and that the equilibrium is not efficient in the sense of Pareto. We can prove a similar proposition for the game that we have defined.1 Indeed, we have:

list-item.p: Proposition 1. When the game of circular external effects is played once and for all, action B is a strictly dominant strategy for each and every individual and the unique Nash equilibrium is that any player chooses it. The vector where each and every individual chooses action A, however, dominates in the sense of Pareto the equilibrium vector.

sec.p: It is also well-known that it is a min–max profile for both players to defect in the prisoner’s dilemma. Similarly, we can prove in the general case the following:

list-item.p: Proposition 2. The Nash equilibrium of the stage game of circular external effects is a min–max profile.

sec.title: III. Some properties of the game of kula
sec.p: We can note the game of kula reduces to the indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma when n = 2. As an intermediate step in our analysis, we will thus generalise to the game of kula some properties of the indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma.

Now, it is well-known that the indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma has always one equilibrium such that players defect in each and every period. Indeed, it is known more generally that the indefinite repetition of a Nash equilibrium of a constitutive game is always a subgame-perfect equilibrium of the indefinitely repeated game with discounting that it generates. See, for instance, Fudenberg and Tirole (1991, page 149). We can thus conjecture that the game of kula has at least one equilibrium path along which all players always play action B.
Indeed, let us define All B to be the strategy such that a player plays B unconditionally in each and every period. We can then prove:

list-item.p: Proposition 3. The vector of strategies where all players play All B is a subgame-perfect equilibrium of the infinite-horizon game of kula.

sec.p: When players have a discount factor δ that is high enough or, in short, are patient, the indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma has at least another equilibrium path along which players always cooperate. We can generalise the latter proposition and prove that the game of kula has at least one equilibrium path along which players always play action A, provided they are patient.

Indeed, let us define the trigger strategy for player i in the game of kula to be such that i plays A in period 0; and plays A in period t ≥ 1 if, and only if, all players have always played A in the preceding periods. We can then extend to the game of kula the argument of Friedman’s (1971) theorem and prove:

list-item.p: Proposition 4. When players are patient, the game of kula has a subgame-perfect equilibrium in trigger strategies.

sec.title: IV. Interpretation of the game as a model of the kula
sec.p: Proposition 4 enables us to show one interpretation of the game of kula provides us with a model of the kula. Indeed, let us assume the players who belong to set I are located in space as points along a circle (or, more generally, along any closed curve that does not intersect itself) and that the order of the natural numbers that index them corresponds to an orientation of the circle from left to right, so that τi is to the left of i and ρi is to the right of i (see Figure 1). Let us also interpret action A as ‘to make a gift’ and action B as ‘to abstain’.

Then, the vector (A,A,…,A) of action A by all players corresponds to a flow of goods that goes in a clockwise fashion when the circular game is defined by permutation ρ; and in a counter-clockwise manner, when the circular game is defined by permutation τ. Such is the pattern according to which goods flow in the kula. Since it follows from (6) that all actors prefer an equilibrium in which the kula goes on to one in which it does not, the model implies the kula is a mutually advantageous system of social exchange.

Now, we should add that the kula is a social pattern, not a geographical one. Indeed, if we look at the positions of villages on Malinowski’s Map V, we can see that their broad geometric pattern is that of a ring, but not a perfect one. That has led Hage (1977) to conjecture a primordial kula formed a perfect ring in geographical space and evolved gradually over time into a more irregular shape.

Nevertheless, we can follow Malinowski (1984 [1922], pages 92–93) and call the kula a circuit or a ring, because a participant always received from a given partner gifts of the same type (say, necklaces), and always gave that partner gifts of the other type (say, arm-shells).

Indeed, the two inverse circular permutations that define the game of kula characterize the algebraic structure of a pattern of social interaction. One interpretation of that abstract mathematics refers to actors who are located along a ring in physical space, but that object is only one among many that the structure can represent. In its general interpretation, the game of kula refers to a pattern that puts actors in fixed relations to one another, so that one always receives from a given partner a good or service of the same type, and always gives that partner a good or service of another definite type. Using a metaphor that preserves geometric intuition, we can describe the pattern as a ring in social space. The geography of the kula, then, was a fortunate accident that made transparent the structure of social interaction.

The formal character of the game of kula allows it to model, not only the kula, but also other systems of bidirectional social exchange. Indeed, Bearman (1997) has uncovered a pattern formally similar to the kula behind the exchange of women among residents of Groote Eylandt in the 1940s. He identified the pattern through a statistical analysis of ethnographic data. The process consisted in two opposite flows: one of daughters of a mother’s brother; the other, of daughters of a father’s sister. The pattern could be considered hidden, in that the groups behind which the exchanges took place corresponded neither to the categories of the natives’ own system of classification, nor to those of the ethnographers. As long as such a pattern remains hidden, it naturally escapes explanation. Once it has been identified, however, it can be modelled with the game of kula.

sec.title: V. Social norms in the game of kula
sec.p: Proposition 4 can also be interpreted as a theorem on the constitution of social norms in the game of kula. Indeed, we can define social norms to be rules whereby sanctions are attached to actions. Such a definition is standard among sociologists as well as legal theorists. See, for instance, Horne (2001) and Ellickson (2001). As Kelsen (1967 [1960], page 65) has already pointed out a long while ago, when a norm is in place, we can use words in a tautological manner and call an action good, if, and only if, it conforms to the norm and receives a positive sanction (or reward); and bad, if, and only if, it does not conform and receives a negative sanction (or punishment). The equilibrium in trigger strategies constitutes, therefore, a social norm that makes A the good action; and B, the bad action.

When n = 2, the game of kula reduces to an indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma and we are already familiar with the properties social norms have in that case. Indeed, the equilibrium in trigger strategies constitutes a norm whose sanctions are enforced by the individuals who are affected directly by its respect or violation. For instance, when a player deviates and plays B in a given period, the individual who is harmed by that deviation punishes it by playing B forever afterwards. More generally, all social norms in the indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma are norms of direct reciprocity in the sense of Alexander (1987).

When n ≥ 3, however, social norms in the game of kula have different properties. Consider, for instance, the norm that trigger strategies constitute in the case where n = 3. Then, a deviation by player 1 in period t is punished by players 2 and 3 who, according to their trigger strategies, will always play action B afterwards. Only one of the two players has been harmed, however: player 2, if t is even; or player 3, if t is odd. More generally, since any violation is sanctioned both by the player who has been harmed and by a third party, trigger strategies constitute in the game of kula a social norm that is mixed and involves elements both of direct and indirect reciprocity.

As the indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma, the game of kula has potentially many equilibriums where all players play A in each and every period, besides the equilibrium in trigger strategies. With appropriate values of the parameters, we can show there is at least one that constitutes a pure norm of direct reciprocity whereby a player who deviates is sanctioned only by the player who has been harmed; and there is at least another one that constitutes a pure norm of indirect reciprocity with sanctions by third parties only.

Indeed, on the one hand, let us define the generalized Pavlov strategy for player i as follows: i initially plays A, and then plays A if, and only if, either all players have played A or all players have played B in the preceding period. As its name indicates, that strategy reduces to the Pavlov strategy, in the sense of Nowak and Sigmund (1993), when n = 2. The latter consists for a player to cooperate in the initial period, and then to cooperate whenever both players have played the same action (either cooperation or defection) in the preceding period. It is different from the better known tit-for-tat, which consists for a player to cooperate in the initial period, and then to cooperate whenever the other player has cooperated in the preceding period or to defect whenever the other player has defected. Other names for the Pavlov strategy include ‘perfect tit-for-tat’ (Fudenberg and Tirole, 1991), and ‘win–stay, lose–shift’ (Nowak and Sigmund, 1993). The name ‘Pavlov’ was originally given by Kraines and Kraines (1989) to a somewhat similar strategy that embodied learning by rewards and punishments.

It is well known that for some values of the payoffs in the one-stage game, the couple of perfect tit-for-tat strategies is a subgame-perfect equilibrium of the indefinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma when the two players are patient. See, for instance, Fudenberg and Tirole (1991, page 180). We can prove a similar proposition for the game of kula:

list-item.p: Proposition 5. When payoffs are suitable and players are patient, the vector of generalized Pavlov strategies is a subgame-perfect equilibrium in the game of kula.

sec.p: We can verify the vector of generalized Pavlov strategies constitutes a pure norm of direct reciprocity in the game of kula. Indeed, a single deviation from the norm by player i is sanctioned by the player who has been harmed: player ρi, if the deviation occurs in an even period; or player τi, if it occurs in an odd period. Player i is also sanctioned only by the player who has been harmed. If the deviation occurs in an even period and harms player ρi, player τi who can affect player i only in even periods will continue playing A in those periods. Likewise, if the deviation occurs in an odd period and harms player τi , player ρi who can affect player i only in odd periods will continue playing A in those periods. More generally, a single deviation by player i entails that every player will play B in the period that follows it, but only the change in behaviour by the player who has been harmed will affect i and can be considered a punishment of i’s bad action. The other changes in behaviour are negative externalities of the sanction that fall on other players.

On the other hand, let us define the double-trigger strategy to be such that player i plays A in period 0; player i plays A in even periods if, and only if, each and every player has always played A in even periods; and player i plays A in odd periods if, and only if, each and every player has always played A in odd periods. We can then prove:

list-item.p: Proposition 6. When players are patient, the vector of double-trigger strategies is a subgame-perfect equilibrium in the game of kula.

sec.p: We can verify the vector of double-trigger strategies constitutes a social norm with sanctions by third-parties only. While a deviation by player i in an even period will harm player ρi and player ρi can only affect player i in odd periods, player ρi will nevertheless continue to play A in those periods. It will be player τi who will punish the deviation by playing B in each and every even period afterwards. Similarly, while a deviation by player i in an odd period will harm player τi and player τi can only affect player i in even periods, player τi will nevertheless continue to play A in those periods. It will be player ρi who will punish the deviation by playing B in each and every odd period afterwards. Naturally, as we already explained in the case of the norm constituted by generalized Pavlov strategies, the changes in their behaviour by players who do not affect i cannot be considered punishments of i’s behaviour. Once more, they are negative externalities of the sanction that fall on other players.

Finally, it is clear that a player whose deviation is punished only by the player who has been harmed can also be sanctioned both by the player who has been harmed and by a third party. Similarly, a player who is punished by a third party only can also be sanctioned by the player who has been harmed and the third party taken together. We can therefore expect mixed norms to be more resistant than either pure norms of direct reciprocity or pure norms of indirect reciprocity. Indeed, we can prove:

list-item.p: Proposition 7. If the game of kula has a subgame-perfect equilibrium in generalized Pavlov strategies (or in double-trigger strategies), it has also one in trigger strategies. The converse is not true, however, since it can have a subgame-perfect equilibrium in trigger strategies without having one in generalized Pavlov (or in double-trigger strategies).

sec.p: The social norms constituted by trigger strategies are thus more robust than those constituted either in generalized Pavlov or in double-trigger strategies, as they can exist under a wider range of parameter values.

sec.title: VI. Discussion
sec.p: In the construction of any model, there is a tension between two distinct objectives: realism and tractability. On the one hand, it is desirable that the assumptions correspond as much as possible to the empirical evidence. On the other hand, they have to be strong enough for the model to be solvable analytically. In the end, those objectives are conflicting, and a compromise has to be struck. A reasonable criterion of realism is therefore that a model provides, not an exact description of reality, but a good approximation.
Now, there are two aspects of the game of the kula that deserve to be discussed in that regard: its information structure, and its capacity to explain a kula that persists despite eventual mistakes.

Let us discuss first the information structure. In section II, we assumed the game of kula was played under almost perfect information. Strictly speaking, that assumption is probably false. However, it can be considered an acceptable simplification.

To begin with, we have to recognize that we cannot know the true information structure of the kula, as the anthropological record is not, and cannot be, precise enough for us to know exactly who knew what and when. All we can do is to assume an information structure that seems reasonable, given the indications that we find in the record, and given that those indications are themselves a reconstruction on the part of the anthropologists.

Now, Malinowski made it clear that the participants in the kula kept themselves very well informed about it. For instance, in his description of kula conversations at a feast, Malinowski (1984 [1922], page 214) reports the natives discussed the circuit followed by a necklace and how it passed from whom to whom. Similarly, in his notes of a conversation between kula partners, Malinowski (1984 [1922], page 271) mentions they drew a long list of arm-shells, and named the people who currently possessed them.
On that basis, we assume that the true information structure was close to almost perfect information, and we conclude that the latter is a good approximation of that unknown structure.

A second issue that is worth discussing is the capacity of the model to explain a kula that persists, even when participants are prone to make mistakes. In the language of game theory, that issue is called the trembling-hand perfection of cooperative equilibriums.

Now, from a realist perspective, we can point out that giving a necklace or an arm-shell is a rather simple act, so that a mistake in the kula is a rather unlikely event. In the limit, as the probability of a mistake goes to zero, the expected payoffs become the same whether or not mistakes can happen, so that a vector of strategies is trembling-hand perfect if, and only if, it is subgame-perfect. It follows that the three equilibriums we have discussed are trembling-hand perfect.

Let us reconsider then those three equilibriums. In the one with generalized Pavlov strategies, there will be phases during which the kula will go on normally. Those phases will be interrupted by one round of direct punishment, in the unlikely event of a mistake. After each phase of punishment, the kula will resume. The length of each phase during which the kula goes on normally is random and depends upon the probability of a mistake. As that probability goes to zero, its expected duration becomes arbitrarily long. That argument shows direct reciprocity can support a kula that persists despite mistakes.

In the equilibrium with trigger strategies, there will be two phases, as an initial phase of cooperation will be followed by its definitive collapse, once a mistake occurs. The length of the phase during which the kula goes on is again random, with an expected duration that can be arbitrarily large when mistakes have a probability that is low enough. That argument shows the kula can last a long while under mixed reciprocity, but maybe not indefinitely. It will, however, be used in the construction of another equilibrium where mixed reciprocity supports a kula that persists despite mistakes.

In the equilibrium with double-trigger strategies, there will be three phases. During an initial phase, actors will cooperate and the kula will go on. After a first mistake, there will be a partial collapse of cooperation and the kula flow will end in one direction. A second mistake, then, will trigger the definitive collapse of the remaining half of the kula. Once more, the length of the phase during which the full kula goes on is random, with an expected duration that can be arbitrarily large when mistakes have a probability that is low enough. That argument shows the kula can last a long while under indirect reciprocity, but maybe not indefinitely. It will, however, be used in the construction of an equilibrium where indirect reciprocity supports a kula that always resumes.

In order to construct a fourth equilibrium where mixed reciprocity supports a kula that persists despite mistakes, we can remember that trigger strategies are more a mathematical simplification than a realist hypothesis. Indeed, they can be interpreted as a short-cut to a punishment that lasts long enough.

Let us, therefore, define a truncated trigger strategy to be such that a player keeps on playing A, unless a single deviation occurs. In the latter case, the player plays B for k ≥ 1 period(s) and resumes playing A afterwards. Gintis (2000) has shown that those strategies can provide a trembling-hand perfect equilibrium in the repeated prisoner’s dilemma. We can easily verify that they provide us likewise with a trembling-hand perfect equilibrium in the game of kula. Indeed, in order to do so, it is sufficient to note that the generalized Pavlov is a truncated trigger strategy, with k = 1.

Furthermore, since the equilibrium in trigger strategies is the limit of a vector of truncated trigger strategies when k goes to infinity, we can see there is an equilibrium in truncated trigger strategies with k ≥ 2. We obtain thereby a trembling-hand perfect equilibrium where mixed reciprocity supports a kula that always resumes after k periods of mixed punishment, when a mistake happens. Once more, each of the phases during which the kula goes on normally has a random length.

Finally, we can easily construct a fifth equilibrium in truncated double-trigger strategies, along lines similar to those of the preceding argument. In that equilibrium, there will be phases during which indirect reciprocity will support the full kula. Yet again, each of those phases will have a random duration, as each can be interrupted by an eventual mistake. The latter event will give rise to k rounds of indirect punishment that will suspend the kula flow in one direction, either in successive odd, or in successive even periods. In the generic case, the kula will then resume normally.

Some odd events are also possible. If a second mistake occurs before the punishment triggered by the first is over, it will start k rounds of indirect punishment in the other direction. If the second mistake occurs between any two rounds of the first punishment but the penultimate and the last, there will be a phase during which punishments overlap and suspend the kula in both directions. If it occurs between round k − 1 and round k, the first phase of punishment will be followed by another one during which the kula will be suspended in the other direction. More generally, there can be sequences where punishment in one direction is followed by punishment in the opposite direction, with or without overlap. Since a single mistake has a low probability, however, all those cases have negligible probabilities. In any case, the full kula will resume eventually with probability one. That last argument shows indirect reciprocity can support a kula that persists despite mistakes.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the present paper, I have expounded the construction and analysis of an infinite-horizon game that I called the game of kula. Our discussion had three main objectives. The first was to show that game theoretical models of social norms can be applied, not only to imaginary societies, but also to actual ones. That objective was met in section IV, when we showed the game of kula can model the system of kula as it has been described by Malinowski (1984 [1922]).

The second objective was to provide an explanation of the kula that made the same assumptions about the rationality of its actors that economists make casually about businessmen and financiers in order to explain their behaviour. Since non-cooperative game theory relies upon those assumptions of individual rationality that are standard in economic theory, that objective was met at the onset when we constructed the model in sections I and II.

The third and final objective was to show the kula can be interpreted in terms of direct reciprocity, in terms of indirect reciprocity or in terms of mixed reciprocity. That objective has been met by proving in section V that direct reciprocity and indirect reciprocity are two equilibrium profiles, and by proving in section III that mixed reciprocity, which involves elements of both direct and indirect reciprocity, is a third equilibrium profile. Among those three equilibrium profiles, proposition 7 of section V showed that mixed reciprocity is the more robust. By itself, that result suggests mixed reciprocity is probably a safer interpretation of the kula than the received interpretation of the kula as a system of indirect reciprocity.

Finally, it may be worth pointing out that one could attempt to do for other systems of norms what we have done for the kula. From an empiricist perspective, indeed, the application of game theory to the analysis of social order can be a meaningful part of social science only in as much as it is developed from the interplay between the mathematical models and the social facts they are meant to capture. In that regard, our model of the kula is an invitation to further research.
